There will never be another Donald J. Trump. For his detractors that is sobering relief from their irrational zealotry. For some it ss disquieting and disheartening. 

Right when the convergence into the international global order is nearly at it's zenith for the United States comes a controversial figure and asks a simple question. 

Why? 

That was a question we weren't supposed to be made aware of. Humanity was supposed sleep walk into an age of desolation and dystopian discontent (masked as the Digital Human Revolution, from homo-sapien to superior-man, built of the many back of 'useless eaters.'

The mask slide off and what we have witnessed staring back is not nice. It is a malevolence for humanity masked in transhumanism .

We have a shot, a narrow one. We can turn our back on transhumanism and instead of reaching inward with technology, we can reach outward towards the stars. We might as well, we can make a good job of it while we're waiting on death. 

Jesus Christ is King
God Bless Donald J. Trump
Make America Great Again

THE DEAL. The Trump-Taliban deal was set on Feb 29, 2020 when there were 13,000 US troops in Afghanistan. The deal included the phased release of 5,000 Taliban prisoners.

TALIBAN VIOLATIONS. The Taliban VIOLATED the agreement with attacks in early March and again in early May. On Aug 18, the DOD IG complained that the Taliban continued to violate terms of the agreement. The final release of 5,000 (total) Taliban prisoners was completed on Sep 3, but was quickly followed by Taliban attacks in three provinces, again violating the terms of the agreement. More Taliban attacks were reported by the DOD IG Nov 17 and Dec 2. On Jan 15, 2021, the new VP of Afghanistan complained that the US made too many concessions to the Taliban as US troops were reduced to 2,500 by mid Jan 2021 (10,000+ LESS than a year earlier). With these persistent Taliban violations, why did Trump keep pulling out US troops and release Taliban prisoners?

Just keeping Bagram open without thousands more troops would have made those soldiers sitting ducks as well. Trump never should have let the Taliban off the hook after the Taliban persistently violated terms of the agreement. Net-net, Trump set up the disaster that Biden had to fix.

@@joshspry1 It's a spectrum. Not all things are black and white. It is very person to person dependent. Like most illigal drugs the reason they are illegal is that they are extremely potent. It is very hard to gauge each individuals medibolic rate (how strong the drug will hit them). It is a very delicate thing. A micro dose might do a lot for one person and not affect another at all. It's not that the substance is bad, it's that the spectrum of how it effects people is so diverse.

@@Bachelor_GabeI had something which would probably be described as PTSD, not military related but left with grinding windmills of the mind that would drag me under for weeks... then I'd think I was recovering and back it'd come, went on for about three years until I decided to try philacybin (?).

I did it once, very seriously, alone, in a shelter I'd built myself in the woods (where I was very comfortable) after having an unusually good day... important not to do it if you're not in a good state of mind going into it. I prepared everything for it like I was having a new girlfriend round... but it was me I was treating. But the act of tidying and preparing your living space, preparing food, making the bed etc. is good to centre the mind and important to feel confident so there's minimal opportunity for confusion, everything is prepared and at hand ready. 

Anyway, point being, they probably saved my life that night. Not a miracle cure, my difficulties continued for a while off and on - but after the incredible experience I had that night I knew I had a chance... that I was not permanently broken, that my mind was capable of great joy, love and, most importantly, huge appreciation of the world which was completely absent in that state before... that was the most debilitating thing for me about that condition, not being able to appreciate a beautiful view or whatever because of the dark windmills grinding - they showed me that was still available which was all I really needed, afterwards, when it would return, I had that experience to remind me that the suffering wasn't all there was and that made me stand and fight it in a way I couldn't before. 

So, I just wanted to say... yes, they can help a lot - by the way, for me, going and collecting them myself was very important as it made the whole thing entirely self motivated - going out and collecting them is the first step, and actually taking them from the earth with your own hands is also an important thing rather than them being bought like a consumable - that helps add depth and meaning to the experience. If you do it, do it whole heartedly, make it meaningful, conscientiously, prepare for it, take it seriously... go to meet the Gods and they can change your life - you get out what you put in. 

Read The Immortality Key by Brian Muresku (something like that - it's available on audiobook on audible too) before, I did, and that gave me the right mindset to approach the thing with, I think. 

All the best and have faith brother, there's a wonderful world waiting when you've cleared that blockage. üåû

Look man I'm glad this worked well for you and I'm on the side of decriminalizing all drugs (the war on drugs has claimed more lives than the war on terror and hasn't fixed or benefitted society, go after dealers not users--users are just victims,) but psychedlics aren't harmless. They cause permanent changes in the brain. For you this was positive. For me I have HPPD. I actually have the most extreme case of HPPD in the western world. As someone that's never had a bad trip (I'm naturally positive about myself) this doesn't bother me but if someone else was in my situation they would be overwhelmed. I quit doing psychedilics and drinking alcohol when my kid was born (months before actually.) I still am tripping though and see thick digital static/snow and will for the rest of my life. There is no cure to hppd (1 woman claimed to be cured by lamictal, I don't believe her and the side effects and permanent neurological damage caused by antipsychotics will never be worth trying them,) so when you have hppd you have it. I thought at one point in time it would be cool to trip forever then I grew up some more and had responsibility and goals in life and all that, and I can say it did me little good. Sure it was an interesting experience but I don't think it would be for everyone and for every one that is "cured" of their ptsd there will be someone with hppd. Hppd for many people can become crippling or even disabling if they can't overcome their anxiety and many don't. Many become agoraphobes and can't function without benzodiazepines (which I am also about to begin treatment with through a doctor but don't intend to take daily due to their side effects,) and it's a bad deal. Some people like my lil bro literally never felt depression or anxiety until the first time they tripped (and their first trip was a bad trip,) and then they have never not felt vulnerable to depression after. Psychedelic therapy will require some serious precautions and also all kinds of screening. One of my friends who tripped with me had his schizophrenia triggered. After tripping ONCE. So screening for mental illnesses like that need to be screened which would mean needing hereditary stuff like gene site testing and diagnosis of family members and on and on.
I'm glad you found healing, but mushrooms do not have this outcome for everyone.

@@sirclarkmarz Not sure about lex, but what you say is true. Specifically, Asperger's. I know from a friend of mine: her face gets literally locked up because the raging emotional storm inside her overwhelms her - it is "too much to express with mere words and gestures". Aspies (if I may say so) are literally the most profoundly emotional (and sharp-witted) people in the world, but since they are pretty much normal human beings otherwise, they constantly struggle to express this wealth of emotions and thoughts in a way that is comprehensible to the "mainstream normies", and are thus commonly misunderstood as "cold" and "unemotional" while they are quite the opposite. I always enjoy talking with this sort of people. They suck at lying and cheating, and their bluntness is very refreshing. In a very profound and honest way, not at all like Trump's tedious and constant insults, lies and tantrums. An aspie's word is a word you can trust, because they TOTALLY MEAN IT. They say it straight from the heart, as they see it. Even if I don't agree with their opinion, I do appreciate their inability to sugarcoat things to gain your favor.

Normies ought to treat such people not as "mentally ill". They are simply "normal cranked up to 11". Back in the Renaissance, they were celebrated as genial, and every self-respecting king wanted them as advisors and artists, because they were, in a way, more deeply human than the average human. Consider Mozart, or Leonardo da Vinci - these were, as it is said, "totally on the spectrum", and thus we remember them for a kind of Greatness that is not achievable by "normies".

Also the way things were set up in the past, they were more localized, you'd vote for someone local to represent you in the house of Representatives, and the population was much lower then so a lot of people would have met their representatives, or been to town halls with them, or have known them personally, nobody voted for president or senators. Senators were elected by state representatives who were even more local and voted in by the citizens and the citizens would vote for a more local electorate for the electoral college who would then go and investigate higher realms of politics and decide who to vote for for president. The idea that citizens would vote for a president would have been seen as stupid, especially before TV and internet. Newspapers in the early days were also much more biased because there was no way anyone could fact check them quickly. And often 1 newspaper would dominate an area, so all the citizens in that area would get the news the press businesses wanted them to get. And sometimes they'd just make shit up. John Adams published in the paper that Thomas Jefferson was dead so that people wouldn't vote for him. Voters were not realistically informed at ALL in national political matters, and they weren't meant to be, the people were meant to be represented but not run the government, and they'd be represented by LOCAL representatives in all parts of government. There are many of us ‚Äúover here‚Äù who do in fact think, question, contemplate, refute, and we are well aware that our senior politicians have become untouchable, almost like monarchs. Power is intoxicating and corruptive. It‚Äôs no surprise that there is less accountability in these types of exchanges, but we generally do what we can with what we get. As you undoubtedly know, Americans and Germans are very different in culture. There are aspects of your culture (popular, for example) that translate very poorly to our eyes and ears. That said, while we are all seemingly so different and complex in so many ways, I find that a global commonality in the modern era is that we are also so incredibly ignorant and lacking in self-awareness more often than not, just in the mere fact that we see otherness in everything. As a German, I‚Äôm sure you can see examples of this in your country‚Äôs epic and sometimes tragic  history.
